s.text: Although I don't have any systematic data on this, I suspect that the trend that Landsburg describes would be amplified in the following way: if you read in the newspaper about a theory that has been published in a prestigious scientific journal, it is even more likely to be wrong than an article that is published in a prestigious scientific journal that is not widely reported.
ARTICLE: Everyday Economics: Too True To Be Good

Reporters and editors decide what hypotheses are newsworthy and likely to evoke interest in their readers and, for the same reasons discussed in Landsburg's article, this selection criteria are not especially effective at selecting the true scientific hypothesis.

The line of argument seems to be that since hypotheses in academic economics have not been confirmed means that the same would be true for all fields whether theoretical or experimental, and therefore fields that rest on empirical evidence must be castles in the sky.
Other characters are only shown reacting to the sound of the gunshot.
[S]aying that our only hope is to cultivate a kind of stoned aesthetic detachment whereby even a man with his brains blown out becomes an object of beauty and a signpost to a Higher Power.
[S]aying that our only hope is to cultivate a kind of stoned aesthetic detachment whereby even a man with his brains blown out becomes an object of beauty and a signpost to a Higher Power.
Although the original studies received a great deal of attention and are widely accepted, the serious problems with them have not been discussed in the media.

An article cannot take more than several months to transit from first writing until publication or it will be completely out of date, as there are a half dozen groups working on closely related experiments who will have reported *their* results.
